> # [Thousands still missing as Congo flood survivors search for relatives](https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/Congolese civilians gather after the death of their family members following rains that destroyed buildings and forced aid workers to gather mud-clad corpses into piles in the village of Nyamukubi, Kalehe territory in South Kivu province of the Democratic Republic of Congo May 6, 2023. > **[1/2]** Congolese civilians gather after the death of their family members following rains that destroyed buildings and forced aid workers to gather mud-clad corpses into piles in the village of Nyamukubi,... Read more
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> KALEHE, Democratic Republic of Congo, May 9 (Reuters) - The death toll from flooding in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo crept higher on Tuesday as aid workers found more bodies among the muddy devastation and wounded residents succumbed to their injuries in an underequipped local clinic.
> 
> The floods, in a remote, mountainous area of South Kivu province, ripped through the riverside villages of Nyamukubi and Bushushu five days ago, razing houses, destroying crops and killing more than 400 people.
> 
> It was the deadliest natural disaster in recent Congo history.
> 
> Survivor Paul Serushago was still searching for the bodies of two family members on Tuesday, digging with a spade in the mud and debris that reached halfway up the doorway of their home in Nyamukubi.
> 
> "We've been looking for them since Friday and we haven't found them yet," he said, taking a short break from the back-breaking work.
> 
> The scale of destruction has highlighted the vulnerability of people to climate change in many parts of Africa, where poor urban planning and weak infrastructure means communities often cannot withstand increasing bouts of extreme weather.
> 
> In Nyamukubi, entire neighbourhoods have been run over with boulders, and the stink of dead bodies wafts from the earth, a Reuters reporter at the scene said. The homeless are packed into the few public buildings left intact, with poor sanitation.
> 
> The Red Cross believes that over 8,000 people are in need of assistance. Aid efforts have been hobbled by a lack of access and resources.
> 
> "We're not able to deal with this many bodies as urgently as needed. We're searching for bodies with spades, with hands," said John Kashinzwe Kibekenge, spokesperson for the Red Cross in South Kivu province.
> 
> More than 5,500 people remain unaccounted for, local administrator Thomas Bakenga Zirimwabagabo said.
> 
> Government officials brought blankets, food and a few coffins to Nyamukubi on Tuesday. They donated money to a local clinic where three people died on Tuesday, and gave around $1,100 each to 200 affected families.
> 
> But the delegation did not take part in burials as planned or visit Bushushu, where the death toll is believed to be greater because it was market day when the flood hit.
> 
> Residents are terrified. Many wept for lost loved ones, trampled crops and ruined houses. Some asked the government to rehouse them away from a zone where water rushes off the lush hillsides, swelling the river that runs past their houses.
> 
> Aid workers put the dead in mass graves dug over the weekend, drawing complaints from civil society groups and prompting the government to promise assistance for more dignified burials.
> 
> Reporting by Djaffar Sabiti Writing by Sofia Christensen Editing by Christina Fincher
> 
> Our Standards: [The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.](https://www.thomsonreuters.com/en/about-us/trust-principles.html)

For those unfamiliar with Jacksonville, the city had a massive scandal where Curry and his cronies try to sell off the public utility company JEA to the parent company of FPL. 

JEA is one of the largest public utilities in the nation and FPL is a [corrupt mess of a company](https://www.npr.org/2023/01/25/1151453870/fpl-florida-power-ceo-eric-silagy) that has been gouging Florida ratepayers and running a shadow influence campaign on behalf of state Republicans. Needless to say folks were not happy to hear about plans to sell it to FPL. The scheme was ultimately derailed by a combination of fantastic investigative journalism from the Florida Times Union, and the voters caring enough about public ownership of their utilities to pressure Curry to drop the scheme. Highly encourage reading the Times Union expose. There's some good stuff in there. 

 https://stories.usatodaynetwork.com/moneyandpower/home/
article_title: Democrat Donna Deegan becomes first female mayor of Jacksonville

parent_comment: It's important to understand what is distinct about this. Past efforts at brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) focus on providing computer input based on thoughts. That is not the same as mind reading--it is much more limited. It is a much harder task to take an unwilling mind and gather what it is thinking. The moral problem with what Jerry Tang is doing is that there is virtually no added benefit to general thought reading technology (because the same benefits are possible through BCIs), but there are massive and inevitable destructive consequences to privacy, dignity, and justice if this technology is brought to commercial or government use. And, like many greedy, power-hungry AI researchers, he tags on 'oh yeah, and we have to do smth abt ethics' at the end without any indication that he actually be 'proactive' or 'preemptive'. If anything, he is developing the weapon with the defense as an afterthought. Such people are willing to sell out the rights of the nation for their own sakes.
article_title: Mind-reading machines are here: is it time to worry?

text: Outing children to parents ESPECIALLY in red states where bigot parents proudly post publicly how they’d rather their kid die than be lgbtq+ is never a good idea. Maybe parents need to not be bigots so their kids feel safe to talk to them themselves.
parent_comment:
I don’t understand this bill.  I don’t have a problem with school officials making sure parents know about pronoun preferences so parents can talk to their kids and help them with whatever they need.  Ideally, parents already know and have urged their kids to identify publicly when they’re comfortable.

But why the blanket prohibition on “human sexuality instruction”? Is this even an issue?  I don’t think any curriculum has instruction on even human biology before 4th grade, but what about accelerated classes for students that have an interest in science?  

Now if a kindergartener asks “where do babies come from” the teacher can’t even broad strokes answer the question?  Seems dumb - schools are a place of learning.

Edit:  After discussion, the implementation of the parental notification will silence LGBTQ+ kids and make them feel even more isolated.  The purpose of the notification requirement isn’t to pair up kids who are ready to publicly transition with an ally teacher/administrator to discuss with parents.  I think we’re all in agreement that LGBTQ+ kids oftentimes carry around a tremendous burden because they can’t talk to anyone.  This law won’t fix this - forcing conversation without advocacy AND the express permission of the kid isn’t the answer to making schools more open and accepting.
article_title: Indiana governor signs bills targeting LGBTQ students

parent_comment:
Outside of the problematic example of US v. Cruikshank (which is a deeply racist ruling in of itself), and the obvious example of Pressler v. Illinois, there are actually a couple of other examples in which SCOTUS ruled in favor of gun regulations, and in effect consider them a collective right in of effect.

​

[Robertson v. Baldwin](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/165/275/#:~:text=to%20keep%20and%20bear%20arms%20(Art.%20II)%20is%20not%20infringed%20by%20laws%20prohibiting%20the%20carrying%20of%20concealed%20weapons): the right of the people to keep and bear arms (Art. II) is not infringed by laws prohibiting the carrying of concealed weapons.

[Voisine v. United States](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/579/14-10154/): reckless misdemeanour domestic violence does in fact serve as enough basis to bar someone from possessing and carrying firearms and that the Lautenberg Amendment of 1996 is indeed not unconstitutional.

text:
Hold them all to account!  

Aside, it's interesting to watch the press scramble to get this story that they were not expecting and that happened on the weekend to press and on air and the internet.  They are exposing the skeleton crews that run the newspaper, TV and online news orgs.  Most of this reporting is good but what I'd call late and not as in-depth as it needs to be, but they are getting there.  

The national press is wrapped up in debt ceiling talk and Trump's endless meltdown.  Austin's bench of political coverage journalists is not that deep because many have been driven off by mergers, consolidation, downsizing, the pandemic, etc leading to forced early retirement and replacement by overworked virtual interns filing online 400 word pseudo-stories from their apartment or cell phone, just regurgitating press releases and covering the facts that are aggregated online after the event is recorded.  No longer do we have the press corps who had deep ties and old friendships and insider contacts at the ready.  Someone should have seen this coming before hand, this isnt something that happened in a day, not really.  It was settled in a day but this has been a long time coming.
